title: First Flight: NACA 0012 Lift Prediction
description:
Welcome to your first CFD challenge! The NACA 0012 is a symmetric airfoil commonly used in aircraft tail surfaces and helicopter rotors.

**Your Task**: Run a simulation of the NACA 0012 airfoil at 5° angle of attack and Reynolds number of 1 million. Predict the lift coefficient (CL) and verify it matches theoretical expectations.

**Learning Objectives**:
- Understand how angle of attack affects lift
- Interpret lift coefficient (CL) values
- Visualize pressure distribution around an airfoil
- Learn about symmetric airfoils

**Success Criteria**: Achieve CL between 0.50 and 0.60 (±0.05 tolerance)
hints: Start by setting up the simulation with the specified parameters: NACA 0012, α=5°, Re=1e6
Run the simulation and check if it converges. XFoil should converge quickly for these conditions.
Look at the Cp (pressure coefficient) distribution - you should see lower pressure on the upper surface (creating lift).
learning_objectives: Understand the relationship between angle of attack and lift coefficient
Learn to interpret pressure coefficient distributions
Recognize convergence indicators in CFD simulations

reference_solution.explanation: The NACA 0012 at α=5° produces moderate lift. Being symmetric (zero camber), the moment coefficient is near zero.
